title: Walmart’s Plan to Return Value to Shareholders - Yahoo Finance
text:
A Walmart Investor Update: 3-Year Earnings and Growth Outlook 
( Continued from Prior Part )
Walmart’s share repurchase plan At its 22nd Annual Meeting for the Investment Community on October 14, 2015, Walmart (WMT) announced a new $20 billion share buyback plan. It expects to deploy excess cash in buying back its own shares from the open market over the next two years. The company also announced the retirement of the $8.6 billion worth of authorization remaining on its $15 billion existing share buyback plan.
Walmart has repurchased shares worth more than $15 billion over fiscal 2012 to fiscal 2015. This year, it has bought back shares worth $1.7 billion year-to-date.

Dividends Walmart is a dividend aristocrat, one of the few companies in the S&P 500 Index that has raised dividends for a period of at least 25 consecutive years. Walmart has hiked its dividend per share (or DPS) for 42 consecutive years. It’s projecting a dividend per share of $1.96 in fiscal 2016, up 2.1% from the $1.92 per share paid out last year.
Fellow dividend aristocrat Target (TGT) is aiming at a dividend payout ratio of 40%, with a 5%–10% increase in annual dividends through fiscal 2020.
Walmart currently has a dividend yield of 3.3% compared to the following peers as of October 16, 2015:
Target (TGT) – 2.8% Costco (COST) – 4.3% Kroger (KR) – 1% Walmart and Target make up ~2.1% of the portfolio holdings in the SPDR S&P Dividend ETF (SDY) and 1.4% of the holdings in the iShares Russell 1000 Value ETF (IWD).
Implications The announced dividend and share buybacks are likely to provide some appeasement to Walmart shareholders in the face of anticipated headwinds over the next few years. But the fundamentals of what’s behind the value return plan are more troublesome.
The declines in EPS (earnings per share) projected for fiscal 2016 to fiscal 2019 include the impact of the buybacks. This understates the actual decline in earnings from Walmart’s operations. It may also imply that Walmart is anticipating a period of moderating earnings growth.
